Award.AwardTitle: Probing the Role of Glia in Neuronal Function and Behavior in Drosophila
Award.AbstractNarration:
The primary potential benefit of this research is to help understand how brain cells (known as neurons and glia) work together to generate behavior. The researchers will use genetic techniques to identify small populations of glial cells in the fly brain and carry out experiments to determine how they regulate fly locomotion. Relative to humans, the fly brain has fewer cells and can be readily manipulated. Because fruit flies share similar genes and general principles of brain cell structure and function with other animals, insights gained from this project will increase our understanding of glial function in the brains of these animals, including humans. This project will train students and postdoctoral scholars, including students from underrepresented groups. The research team will participate in 'Brain Awareness Week,' a 'Saturday Morning Science' seminar series and other activities that serve the public in local communities. They will work with teachers to conduct fly genetics science projects in middle and high schools.

Using a newly developed genetic method (FINGR, flippase-induced intersectional Gal80/Gal4 repression), the researchers will conduct a forward genetic screen to identify subsets of glial cells that modulate fly locomotion, refine broad glia into smaller units, map glial morphology, perturb glial function, correlate behavioral changes with specific subsets of glia, and examine the impact of the glial subset on neuronal function and morphology. The screen is unbiased, and thus, will provide unprecedented opportunities for studying the effects of specific subsets of glia on neuronal function. Results from this research will also be disseminated through scientific meetings and through publication of peer-reviewed journal articles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The brain has two major resident cells, neurons and glia. In order to fully understand the whole brain, it is essential to understand its parts, both neurons and glia, and how they work together. At present, glial cells are relatively poorly understood. This proposal studies the roles of glia in neural function and behavior. The major intellectual merits of the research are discovering new functions for different types of glia and achieving a better understanding of the mode by which glia communicate with neurons. Using powerful genetics, the researchers were able to reveal a number of previous unknown aspects of glia and their influences on behaviors like locomotion (walking and climbing) and sleep. They also discovered new genes that regulate how glia communicate with neurons to shape behavior. The information obtained from this project advances our basic knowledge of glia and the brain. This proposal also had significant broader impacts on mentoring younger generation of scientists and on outreaching to the general public. With hands-on research, high school and college students gained rich experiences in scientific thinking and practical skills. They shared their experiences and knowledge with peers and families. More importantly, this project provided critical opportunities to train graduate students and postdoctoral fellows in critical thinking skills and independence.
